review.title: A Data Mining framework to model Consumer Indebtedness with Psychological Factors
review.abstract: Modelling Consumer Indebtedness has proven to be a problem of complex nature. In this work we utilise Data Mining techniques and methods to explore the multifaceted aspect of Consumer Indebtedness by examining the contribution of Psychological Factors, like Impulsivity to the analysis of Consumer Debt. Our results confirm the beneficial impact of Psychological Factors in modelling Consumer Indebtedness and suggest a new approach in analysing Consumer Debt, that would take into consideration more Psychological characteristics of consumers and adopt techniques and practices from Data Mining.
histories: IEEE International Conference of Data Mining: The Seventh International Workshop on Domain Driven Data Mining 2014 (DDDM 2014)
review.COMMENTS: IEEE International Conference of Data Mining: The Seventh International Workshop on Domain Driven Data Mining 2014 (DDDM 2014)

sections.heading: B. Two-class models
sections.text: In Figure 5, we can see the performance of models based on a single set of variables. However, we can see that financial variables have the strongest predictive capability among the five different groups, while psychological factors come second and demographic variables come third. It is clear that psychological factors have a significant predictive capability and perform better than the demographic variables traditionally included in economic models of indebtedness. In the case of demography, the performance of demographic variables is worse, but comparable to the original demographic variables, the worst performance of all five groups and, in particular, the greatest decline manifests itself in the case of financial dimensions. A fact that implies a significant loss of information.

sections.heading: C. Three-class models
sections.text: In fact, we are able to put ourselves at the top without being able to put ourselves at the top.

sections.heading: D. Random Forests Analysis
sections.text: In our results it is clear that we can build a good model for distinguishing debtors from non-debtors, but building a more reliable and accurate model that predicts the level of debt requires deeper and more complex research. Of the two-tier models Random Forests showed the best performance. More precisely, the model achieves an accuracy of 72%, 70% sensitivity (true positive rate) and 74% specificity (true negative rate). Random Forests also provide an opportunity to assess the variable meaning by using the mean decline of the Gini index as a measure. Gini Index measures the impurity of the data and therefore the attribute that causes the greatest decrease in impurity is considered as a significant predictor. Looking at the values of this measure, which are summarized in descriptive statistics of Table 6, we can find that more than the 75% of the attributes that have a measured meaning, which is less than the mean importance of all the attributes, are the mean importance of all the attributes.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we examined the multi-layered nature of consumer debt in a complete and detailed socio-economic dataset containing psychological information. After identifying and verifying the psychological factors in the dataset, we proceeded to evaluate their contribution to the modelling of consumer debt within a complete data-mining framework, with powerful classification models and reliable evaluation techniques. It was found that all psychological factors increase the performance of the models in any case in a statistically significant sense. In particular, impulsivity, a well-researched psychological factor [6], [17] appears to be the strongest predictor in our modelling. Our results also suggest that consumer debt analysis has much to gain by embracing the study of psychological factors and the application of data-mining approaches in its methods and practices. Despite the fact that the transformations we have carried out at the socio-economic level have no impact on the modelling methodology if these factors are not taken into account in their final dimensionality.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: We would like to thank John Gathergood, Lecturer in the School of Economics at Nottingham University, for providing the DebtTracl survey.

referenceMentions.context: In Economics, modelling Consumer Indebtedness traditionally adopted the “rational” behaviour of debtors [17], limiting the research on socio-economic variables.

But recent interdisciplinary studies show that the behaviour of consumers deviates from the “rational” model [17] and that level of debt prediction is not a function of economic factors exclusively [20], [13], [19].

But recent interdisciplinary studies show that the behaviour of consumers deviates from the “rational” model [17] and that level of debt prediction is not a function of economic factors exclusively [20], [13], [19].

Now Consumer Indebtedness is considered a phenomenon with distinct facets [9], [18], which is influenced by several psychological factors and entails a magnitude of privetal, societal and economic implications.

Now Consumer Indebtedness is considered a phenomenon with distinct facets [9], [18], which is influenced by several psychological factors and entails a magnitude of privetal, societal and economic implications.

First of all, as the authors in [14] point out that no clear and conceptual model of Consumer Indebtedness has yet emerged despite the fact that many factors influencing Consumer Debt have been proposed in literature, which so far has focused on a few or a subset of demographic, economic, psychological and situational factors, thus limiting, its predictive ability and its generalizability [18].

Secondly, the research has been carried out by statistical models with weak predictive ability [12] that face numerous difficulties when they deal with real world data.
This dataset gives us the opportunity to research the multifaceted nature of Consumer Indebtedness as it is described in [9], [18].

The superior performance of these models in modelling Consumer Indebtedness has been established in our previous study [12]and therefore they pose as reliable models to draw conclusions from safely.
Our results show that Psychological Factors are significant predictors of Consumer Indebtedness confirming the multifaceted nature of the problem [9], [18].
Our results show that Psychological Factors are significant predictors of Consumer Indebtedness confirming the multifaceted nature of the problem [9], [18].

Our final model manages to exhibit a good predictive ability and thus can be considered as the first step towards a complete and well specified model of Financial Indebtedness, as described in [18] which should include all the additional and necessary factors for Consumer Debt Analysis.

The research for Consumer Debt Analysis has been mainly focused on answering three fundamental questions as they are formulated in [19]:

The extensive list of factors that is presented in the literature of this field comes to supplement well researched socio-economic factors that have been traditionally used in economic models to explain Consumer Debt like, work status, net wealth and number of children in household [17] and income, age, gender, education in [9].

The extensive list of factors that is presented in the literature of this field comes to supplement well researched socio-economic factors that have been traditionally used in economic models to explain Consumer Debt like, work status, net wealth and number of children in household [17] and income, age, gender, education in [9].

While an abundance of factors has been suggested to be related to Consumer Debt, articles like [19], [9], [18], [10] provide a nice review of the factors proposed and nice overview of the ongoing research in the field.

Considering Impulsivity or Self Control the work in [6] revealed a significant association with Consumer Debt, especially in the cases of credit cards, mail order catalogues, home credit and payday loans.
In [17] Impulsivity was found a strong predictor of Unsecured Debt but not Secured Debt, like mortgages and car loans.

The rationale behind this, stems from the fact that Secured Debt affects decisions that last for a long time and therefore is linked to Life-Cycle theory [20], according to which consumer enter into debt on rational grounds in order to maximise utility and thus is not associated with Impulsive behaviour which favours short run benefits like the ones Unsecured Debt usually provides.
Finally in [18] a multifaceted model of Consumer Indebtedness is confirmed where all the groups of variables are important in a combined model and not as single predictors.
On the other hand the necessity of incorporating Data Mining in the analysis of socio-economic data is emphasised in [8].
In [12] Random Forests and Neural Networks exhibited superior performance in modelling Consumer Indebtedness than the ones presented in Economic Psychology literature.

Random Forests have been utilised in marketing applications like [7] where a model measuring the impact of the reviews of products in sales and perceived usefulness was constructed, whereas Neural Networks have been used in Economics for for stock performance modelling [16] and for credit risk assessment [1].

This highlights the contribution of Data Mining in developing accurate quantitative prediction models for Economic application, as dictated in [1].
DebtTrack Survey [6] is a quarterly repeated cross-section survey of a representative sample of UK households.

The most interesting aspect of this dataset is that it contains 28 questions that measure Psychological characteristics like Impulsivity and Risk aversion, which gives us the opportunity to explore the multifaceted “nature” of Consumer Indebtedness on a complete dataset by the standards specified in [18]
The choice was based on the well established relationship between Unsecured Debt and Impulsivity [17], which is a Psychological factor that is verified in our dataset.

For this reason we decided to move to a two-class classification (In Debt, No Debt) which is more balanced with 652 consumers being in Debt and 601 build models that can discriminate the debtors from non-debtors, a fundamental research question of Consumer Debt Analysis [19].

Imbalanced classes is a traditional problem in Data Mining [2], [15] but while a lot of sophisticated methods have been presented in literature they are usually not suitable for a multiclass model [15].

Homogeneity analysis (Homals) [4], [3], is a method very similar to correspondence analysis.
Homogeneity analysis (Homals) [4], [3], is a method very similar to correspondence analysis.

As this representation of Homals proved to be successful in our previous work on modelling Consumer Indebtedness [12] as they increased the predictive power of all our models we decided to keep these transformed variables, getting two Demographic Dimensions and two Financial Dimensions.

In order to define the optimal number of factors that describe best the Psychological items, we utilised the Scree test and Parallel Analysis two widely used techniques in applied EFA for determining the number of latent factors [5].
We chose an orthogonal rotation of the factors despite the many advantages of obliques rotation [5] because uncorrelated predictors is much desired in Data Mining models.

All of our models are built in R using the caret package [11] and for Neural Networks we use one hidden layer of neurons and we tune the number of neurons in this layer by keeping the model with the best performance from all the possible models with neurons varying from one to ten.
While this gives better chances to build models to separate debtors from nondebtors, trying to predict the level of debt remains one of the important questions of Consumer Debt Analysis [19].

Finding Impulsivity being the strongest predictor among of all the variables confirms the findings of [6], [17], where it was mentioned to be strongly associated with Consumer Debt, especially its Unsecured forms of debt.

Towards this direction, we would like to continue exploring the multifaceted nature of Consumer Indebtedness by examining the contribution of more factors like Financial Illiteracy which is mentioned in the literature [6] to be associated with Consumer Debt.

metadata.abstractText: Modelling Consumer Indebtedness has proven to be a problem of complex nature. In this work we utilise Data Mining techniques and methods to explore the multifaceted aspect of Consumer Indebtedness by examining the contribution of Psychological Factors, like Impulsivity to the analysis of Consumer Debt. Our results confirm the beneficial impact of Psychological Factors in modelling Consumer Indebtedness and suggest a new approach in analysing Consumer Debt, that would take into consideration more Psychological characteristics of consumers and adopt techniques and practices from Data Mining.
